Description: Wheel-made pottery lamp with a low body, a central tube and a wide overhanging rim with a beaded outer edge, which slopes in towards the centre. The tapering nozzle has a rounded tip and a large oval wick-hole. The underside is turned, and has an incised branch pattern. Decorated with a dark brown slip on the nozzle, oil-chamber, tube and rim. Light brown fabric with organic and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Parallel from Athens (Howland 1958, Type 12A). Parallels from Sardis (end of the 6th century BC and before a 499 BC destruction layer) and Megara Hyblaea (Bailey 1977, 95). See GR 1888,0601.147 also from Naukratis. Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals. Princeton.
Bibliographic references: Lamp / Catalogue of the Lamps in the British Museum (Q150.bis)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KC.05) (Phase 1)
